MINUTES, NAEB, REGION II MEETING, ATLANTA
APRIL 1-2, 19&
Region II Membership of NAEB, mat in Atlanta, April 1-2, in the WABE studios. City
Hall*
Present were: Haskell Bpyter, Atlanta; Vernon Bronson, Miami; Paul Carpenter, Jr,,
AtlantaJ Ken Christiansen, Southern Regional Education Board, Atlanta; Roy Flynn,
Tallahassee3 A3. Gaines, Atlanta! Margaret Kilian, Atlanta} Lillian Lee, Atlanta;
Ken Wright* Knoxville; Earl Wynn, Chapel Hill; John Young, Chapel Hill, and Frank
Schooley, President of NAEB,
Earl Wynn, director Region II, served as Chairman,
The tentative agenda for the meeting was approved. The morning session was given
over to a discussion of {|NAEB Members Look at the National Organization and at
Themselves,”
There was general agreement among the participants that a policy statement of the
national organization should emphasize:
1, that educational broadcasters are first of all educators,
2, that educational radio and television have the same authority and same
responsibility as the institution which they represent.
Further such a statement should by implied or explicit purpose encourage any in¬
stitution which broadcasts to become NAEB members. Such a policy statement also
should be designed to position radio and television as broadcast media of equal
potential and responsibility. There was a feeling among some of the members that
the breech between radio and television was reaching dangerous proportions. There¬
fore, the national organization ought not to close its eyes to this problem.
The policy statement of NAEB should honestly interpret NAEB8 s representation of the
low power station. Recognition was made of the feelings expressed by the High
Point and Greensboro operations through Mr, Young namely, that NAEB doesn3t con¬
cern itself with the problems of the 10 watter,
A sub-committee, Bronson, Chairman, Gaines, Kilian, and Christiansen were appointed
to do a redraft of the NAEB policy statement.
The afternoon meeting was concerned with programmings Without considering mechanics
of distribution, consideration and discussion was made of what programs now being
produced are exportable and could be used by other stations in the region. The
program offerings of the several stations were reviewed with this matter of exporta¬
bility in mind.
Although only station WUNC (University of North Carolina), WABE (Atlanta Board of
Education), WUOT (University of Tennessee), WTHS (Dade County Board of Public In¬
struction), and WFSU (Florida State University) were represented, it became clearly
apparent from the number of programs now being produced by these five stations
that there are a great many programs in Region II of considerable value not only
to other stations in the Region, but perhaps also through the NAEB Tape Network
to the whole national family of educational radio stations. The programs mentioned
are too numerous and Involved to describe here. There were, however, twenty pro-
grams named and described which in the opinion of your director are exportable.
